shortDescription: The Jewish hope for a promised deliverer who would restore Israel, establish God's kingdom, and usher in the age to come.
fullDescription: Messianic expectation in Second Temple Judaism encompassed diverse hopes for divine intervention and restoration. Based on prophetic promises, Jews awaited a descendant of David who would reign in righteousness, the return of Elijah as herald, the restoration of Israel, and the establishment of God's kingdom on earth. John the Baptist's ministry ignited intense messianic speculation, with people asking if he was the Christ, Elijah, or the Prophet. When Andrew encountered Jesus at the Jordan, he recognized the fulfillment of these hopes, immediately declaring to Peter: 'We have found the Messiah' (John 1:41).

content:
# Messianic Expectation in Second Temple Judaism

## The Nature of Jewish Messianic Hope

Messianic expectation in the Second Temple period (516 BCE - 70 CE) was not a single, uniform belief but a constellation of hopes based on prophetic promises. The term 'Messiah' (Hebrew: Mashiach; Greek: Christos) means 'anointed one,' referring to the ancient practice of anointing kings and priests with oil.

## Prophetic Foundations

### The Davidic Covenant (2 Samuel 7:12-16)

> "When your days are fulfilled and you rest with your fathers, I will set up your seed after you, who will come from your body, and I will establish his kingdom. He shall build a house for My name, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever."

This covenant established the expectation of an eternal Davidic kingdom and a future righteous king.

### Isaiah's Messianic Oracles

> "For to us a child is born, to us a son is given; and the government shall be upon his shoulder, and his name shall be called Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God, Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace. Of the increase of his government and of peace there will be no end, on the throne of David and over his kingdom." (Isaiah 9:6-7)

> "There shall come forth a shoot from the stump of Jesse, and a branch from his roots shall bear fruit. And the Spirit of the LORD shall rest upon him." (Isaiah 11:1-2)

### Jeremiah's Righteous Branch

> "Behold, the days are coming, declares the LORD, when I will raise up for David a righteous Branch, and he shall reign as king and deal wisely, and shall execute justice and righteousness in the land." (Jeremiah 23:5)

### Daniel's Son of Man

> "I saw in the night visions, and behold, with the clouds of heaven there came one like a son of man, and he came to the Ancient of Days and was presented before him. And to him was given dominion and glory and a kingdom." (Daniel 7:13-14)

## Diverse Messianic Expectations

### The Royal Messiah (Son of David)
- A king from David's line who would restore Israel's political independence
- Would defeat Israel's enemies and establish God's kingdom
- Expected to reign in righteousness and justice
- Central expectation in most Jewish circles

### The Priestly Messiah
- Some groups (especially Qumran) expected a priestly messiah alongside the royal one
- Would purify Temple worship and teach the Torah correctly
- Based on promises regarding the Levitical priesthood (Malachi 2:4-7)

### The Prophet Like Moses
- Based on Deuteronomy 18:15-18
- Expected a prophetic figure to arise who would speak God's words
- Sometimes identified with Elijah or a separate eschatological prophet

### Elijah's Return
> "Behold, I will send you Elijah the prophet before the great and awesome day of the LORD comes. And he will turn the hearts of fathers to their children and the hearts of children to their fathers." (Malachi 4:5-6)

- Elijah expected to return before the Messiah
- Would prepare the people through repentance and reconciliation
- John the Baptist came 'in the spirit and power of Elijah' (Luke 1:17)

## John the Baptist and Messianic Expectation

### Questions at the Jordan
John 1:19-27 records the priests and Levites asking John:
- "Who are you?" (hoping he might claim to be the Messiah)
- "Are you Elijah?" (the expected forerunner)
- "Are you the Prophet?" (the prophet like Moses)

John's answers revealed intense messianic expectation in his day.

### John's Proclamation
- "One who is more powerful than I is coming" (Mark 1:7)
- "I baptize you with water, but he will baptize you with the Holy Spirit" (Mark 1:8)
- "Behold, the Lamb of God, who takes away the sin of the world!" (John 1:29)

## Andrew's Recognition

### The Moment of Discovery
> "The next day again John was standing with two of his disciples, and he looked at Jesus as he walked by and said, 'Behold, the Lamb of God!' The two disciples heard him say this, and they followed Jesus." (John 1:35-37)

Andrew was one of these two disciples of John the Baptist.

### Andrew's Proclamation
> "He first found his own brother Simon and said to him, 'We have found the Messiah' (which means Christ)." (John 1:41)

This is one of the clearest messianic declarations in the Gospels. Andrew recognized that:
- The prophetic expectations were being fulfilled
- John the Baptist was the forerunner, not the Messiah
- Jesus was the one Moses and the prophets had written about (John 1:45)

### Significance of Andrew's Recognition
Andrew's declaration "We have found the Messiah" reflects:
- His grounding in Jewish messianic expectation
- His understanding of John's preparatory role
- His recognition of Jesus as the prophetic fulfillment
- The transition from prophetic preparation to messianic fulfillment

## The Kingdom of God

Both John and Jesus proclaimed: "Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand" (Matthew 3:2; 4:17)

The messianic kingdom was expected to include:
- The restoration of Israel's twelve tribes
- Victory over enemies (including Rome)
- The rebuilding/purification of the Temple
- Universal knowledge of God
- The resurrection of the dead
- The establishment of everlasting righteousness

## Qumran and the Essenes

The Dead Sea Scrolls reveal expectations at Qumran:
- Two Messiahs: one priestly (of Aaron), one royal (of Israel)
- The Teacher of Righteousness as a preparatory figure
- Imminent expectation of the "end of days"
- Ritual purification through water immersion (mikveh)

## Jesus' Fulfillment

The New Testament presents Jesus as fulfilling multiple strands of messianic expectation:
- Son of David (Matthew 1:1; Romans 1:3)
- Prophet like Moses (Acts 3:22-26)
- Suffering Servant (Isaiah 53; 1 Peter 2:24)
- Son of Man with divine authority (Mark 14:62)
- Eternal Priest after Melchizedek (Hebrews 7)
- The one Moses wrote about (John 1:45; 5:46)

phineasTradition.model: Phinehas who killed for God's honor (Numbers 25)
phineasTradition.theology: Violent zeal for God is praiseworthy and covenant-making
phineasTradition.application: The Messiah would wield the sword against God's enemies
